clinical_study.brief_title: Electronic Prescribing and Electronic Transmission of Discharge Medication Lists
clinical_study.official_title: Electronic Prescribing and Electronic Transmission of Discharge Medication Lists to Improve Ambulatory Medication Safety

lead_sponsor.agency: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

collaborator.agency: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)

clinical_study.source: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is twofold:
1. to measure the effects of transitioning from one electronic prescribing system to another in the ambulatory setting on medication errors and human-computer interactions
2. to evaluate the impact of electronic transmission of discharge medication lists to the ambulatory setting on medication discrepancies and adverse drug events

primary_outcome.time_frame: 2 weeks prior, 3 months, 1 year after intervention and 2 years after intervention

primary_outcome.measure: Medication discrepancies (as detected on a comparison between inpatient and outpatient medical records)
primary_outcome.time_frame: 30 days after patient is discharged from hospital

primary_outcome.measure: Patient adverse drug events (as determined by patient telephone interview and medical record review)

secondary_outcome.measure: Human-Computer interactions as measured by physician interview and direct observation of physician work

arm_group.description: All physicians and nurse practitioners at 1 ambulatory care clinics
All physicians and nurse practitioners at 1 ambulatory care clinics

intervention.description: Transition from home-grown to vendor-based ambulatory e-prescribing systems

intervention.intervention_name: Electronic transmission of medication discharge lists
intervention.description: Patient discharge medication lists will be transmitted upon discharge from their inpatient medical record to their outpatient medical record and their outpatient provider will be notified of this transmission.

study_pop.textblock: Physicians and Nurse Practitioners from 2 office practices in the Ambulatory Care Network at NYPH, Associates in Internal Medicine (AIM) on the Columbia campus and Cornell Internal Medicine Associates (CIMA) on the Cornell campus.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Physicians or nurse practitioners with at least 4 clinic sessions per week
